result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

2:57 PM Defendant Riley J. Friend in court.  Attorney Carly June Sebion in court for Riley J. Friend.  Attorney Crystal Leigh Jensen in court for State of Wisconsin. Parties are ready to proceed.  State is in compliance with victim rights. State calls witness, Deputy Sheriff KG, sworn in, states name and employment as a JC Deputy Sheriff. Testifies. Record reflects identification of the defendant.  Cross examination by Attorney Sebion.  Object discover related, sustained. Cross examination continues. No redirect. Defense has no witnesses.  Court finds probable cause bound over trial.  Set for Arraignment on 11/7 @ 3PM.

Preliminary hearing on October 14, 2022 at 03:00 pm.

ALL PARTIES TO THE ACTION SHALL APPEAR IN PERSON FOR THIS HEARING.  THIS HEARING IS NOT BEING HELD VIA ZOOM.

3:02 PM Defendant Riley J. Friend appeared by video.  Attorney Carly June Sebion appeared by video for Riley J. Friend.  Attorney Crystal Leigh Jensen in court for State of Wisconsin. No resolution. Schedule for preliminary hearing, Atty Sebion will contact JA.

Pre-trial conference on August 31, 2022 at 10:00 am.

Court questioned defendant on his understanding of the waiver of preliminary hearing time limits.  He stated he understood.  Court found that the defendant knowingly and intelligently waived his right to have a preliminary hearing within time limits.
